title: I have an idea to rework crit and make marksman have superior sustained damage but weak burst
body:
Crit should be changed from being rng to being something that ramps your damage but faster with more crit. 

What I mean: Crit chance gives each auto after the first on enemy champions and epic monsters within 5 seconds but constantly refreshing on every auto a % increase in auto attack damage by 1/3 of your crit until your 4th auto which makes all your autos do %increased damage equal to crit. Example below of how this works:

{{champion:18}} has 200 total AD, 100% crit chance, and is attacking a {{champion:14}} . If we ignore resistances her first auto deals 200 damage, her second auto deals 266 damage, 3rd auto deals 334 damage, and her 4th auto and beyond deals 400 damage.

An idea i thought of while looking at Darius bleed.

I don't think you adequetely addressed his complaint. He's not making any commentary about whether or not your proposal is healthier than the current system. He's saying that your new system is a lot weaker than the current crit system, and he's right. Your proposal strictly reduces the expected dps from crit until you autoattack someone 4 times, at which point it breaks even. That's weaker than the current crit system, and it would force carries to start using non-crit items.

>Riot wants adcs to be sustained damage dealers (except a few cases) and reworking crit from rng to something more predictable and playable for all players is healthier.

But you're also nerfing it heavily by significantly reducing the dps crit gives you until the fourth autoattack, when it only breaks even with the current system. Regardless of whether or not it's healthier, your proposal does make it a lot weaker.

I mean, it doesn't matter how healthy the system is if it's too weak to actually use, and that's kind of what you've done by making carries ramp up to the same dps that they would have had before the changes.

Yea this system is weaker in short fights but a buff for long battles like teamfights. Current ADCs have been strong for so many seasons this wouldnt make them unviable or "weak" just have a clear moment where they are powerful.

Numbers i put there are just an idea, not what i want it to exactly be.

> buff for long battles like teamfights.

With the numbers you put out, it is strictly a nerf up until the point where you hit 4 attacks, at which point is mathematically the exact same dps that you currently have on live. It's weaker in every fight, no matter what. It literally can't be stronger unless there is a point where the carry can have a higher expected dps with the new system than they do on live.

So, that raises a question: Are you willing to let carries have more damage with the new system than they do on live after a certain number of autoattacks, or is it just going to be a straight nerf? That's not a numbers question, it's a design question. What do you want out of it?

No matter what your answer is though, I dislike the proposal. I think it's homogenizing, and works to hard to force all the champions in a class to play similarly. You're taking a very general stat, used by champions with multiple different playstyles, and you're forcing them into all playing the same way. Right now, the only thing crit encourages is autoattacking. You're changing it into forcing people to autoattack the same target over and over again. You're forcing a playstyle on people by attaching that playstyle to a non-negotiable stat. 

If we're going to derandomize crit, the best way to do it is in a way that is as playstyle-neutral as possible. We should have crit give a %damage increase to autoattacks. That way, playstyle differences can be forced solely by champion kits, not by what kind of stat they're forced to buy. Doing otherwise is way, way too homogenizing. It puts too much important on a playstyle derived from a stat, instead of playstyles derived from their kits.

To put it simply, it's boring, it's dull, and it promotes champions to be similar to each other instead of distinct. That's not healthy for the game. We can achieve any balance goals we're after without having to resort to trying to force homogenization of playstyles on a class.

>You read his idea and then you started commenting on the numbers which isn't relevant to the idea itself.

They absolutely are relevant, becasue the numbers determine what the system actually ends up doing. Is it intended to represent a potential increase in damage after fighting for long enough? Or is it meant solely to be a gate on early damage in a fight? Numbers are the factor that determines that.

Besides, 3/5 of my post had nothing to do with numbers. I criticized the design of making crit attack speed based, and I maintain those criticism. 

>without really changing the play style of marksmen since they will still be basic attacking from range like always

No, as I made a point of, it's a significant change in playstyle, because it encourages autoattacking the same target once you've built up stacks on them. There are carries who very much don't want to do that. Mobile, bursty carries are encouraged to switch targets based on openings in the fight, but this discourages and punishes that. Assassin type carries are supposed to threaten the backlines, which harder if your first attacks are strictly weaker. It also encourages attack speed based builds, because AD focused crit builds will suck dick from not being able to stack fast enough to make crit worthwhile.

If you want something that doesn't change playstyles, then it's very, very simple: %damage increase to autoattacks. Mathematically the same expected dps, and doesn't favor anybody. It's better than OP's proposal.

>and no this doesn't make armorpen builds the new standard crit would still result in higher dps 

If the first 3 autoattacks of a fight are strictly weaker than they are on live, then it absolutely will put pressure on carries to use armor penetration builds. It doesn't matter if it eventually builds up to slightly superior dps if it is strictly weaker every time you attack a new target. Ability focused builds are already only slightly off of being the norm for a lot of AD carries. This could easily push them over the edge.

>It might even lead to more viable build options as well since you could just sit on that one infinity edge and still use it to amp up your dps big time whilst leaving room to buy different attack speed and ad items you would otherwise not really build

This is just so wrong. I have so many criticisms of this one sentence. It makes so many bad assumptions.

There is not a single reason to believe that a playstyle restriction would open up item options. There has never been a point in league's history where restrictions on playstyles opened up options. The game's design disallows that.

Let's enumerate why. First, sitting on one crit item will be worse than before, not better. If you're required to build stacks on enemies in order to make crit effective, then the last thing you want to do is go for low attack speed builds, but high attack speed requires that you buy crit. I'm not going to buy an attack speed reliant dps steroid without actually buying attack speed, and that requires buying more crit.

Second, what "different attack speed and ad items" are you thinking of? For attack speed, are you thinking of zeal items? Because, if you are, you can already stack those. The only other ones are BotRK and Wit's End, and these changes aren't making them any less crappy/situational. As for AD items, you'd still pick those up third or fourth, just like you do now. The only difference is that you won't possibly get them second in any situation because you NEED attack speed to make your early crit effective. All this does is limit a potential option.

I seriously don't think you thought about the items at all when you said that.

Third, there is nothing new about crit being a dps amp. Crit already is a DPS amp. That is explicitly its purpose. 20% crit is a 20% boost to dps. And yet, you don't see people sitting on one crit item on live, because it's mathematically inefficient. If you're looking to maximize dps, then there is a mathematical forumla for how much crit is needed. Having a ramp up doesn't change that. It doesn't make it any more rewarding to sit on one crit item. Maximizing dps will still require multiple items, particularly since all the attack speed items that are viable for a carry to purchase have crit.

Why do you think this would open up build options? Do you have a reason? Are you just thinking that because it's a change, it would open up more options? What's your justification?

That's only if the underlying numbers stay the same.

With his system, it is no longer relevant to cap Crit at 100% Chance. You could, for example, increase crit's numbers on all items by 5-10%, resulting in higher DPS after the ramp-up.

The system is overall an interesting idea to implement such a hyperscaling mechanic in a game.

It's not quite as simple as just changing it directly, due to skills that don't scale as linearly off of critical chance, like Yi's Q or Garen's E.

I do like the idea, though, and you could call the stat Precision rather than Critical Strike Chance.

_Precision: Your basic attack AD ratio is increased by your Precision, up to a maximum of +100._

Infinity Edge would increase both your current Precision and the cap by 50%, preserving its current functionality more or less.

>It's not quite as simple as just changing it directly, due to skills that don't scale as linearly off of critical chance, like Yi's Q or Garen's E.

It is that simple for almost everyone. The same changes will ensure the exact same expected DPS for those abilities as well.

Take Garen: say his spin is doing 100 damage per tick, ticks 10 times, and that he has 50% crit chance. Keep in mind that Garen's E crits add 50% damage instead of 100.

With the current system, we expect 5 hits for 100 damage, and 5 crits for 150 damage, leading to a total damage of 1,250. With a % increase system, all of his ticks would have an increase of 25% (50% crit * 0.5 crit damage modifier) equaling 125 per hit, for a toal of 1,250. 

We can make this work for any ability that increases its damage based on critical chance, and we can make it work with any crit damage modifier too.

The only abilities we would have to adjust are abilities that provide a specific non-damage bonus when you crit (Trynd getting more fury on a crit), or if someone is heavily based on "crit-fishing" gameplay (Trynd's laning phase). Unless you have one of those conditions, the power difference between having a crit-based damage increase or having a consistent damage increase is very, very small. Basically, we'd have to look at Trynd.

I'm not the biggest fan of this, in part because the implementation looks a little fiddly. Just within your system, you'd be better off dividing all of your crit values by 3 and making the autoattack damage increase 1-to-1, and perhaps adding a 3-stack cap on top. My main issue with this, though, is that it kinda defeats both the purpose and feel of crit: critical strikes are supposed to be these awesome explosions of damage that you rack up over time, and this instead creates a ramp-up that leads towards constant damage, which is less interesting. Granted, the current crit system also ends up leading to pretty constant DPS, but this wouldn't be an improvement in that respect.

I personally think a better alternative would be turning crit into a three passive, e.g. deal bonus damage every three autos. It's simple, visible to all, and allows for DPS-based burst, while also being easier to design for. An advantage it has over the above system, too, is that it would be target-specific, meaning you'd have to focus a specific enemy to gain access to crit against them, instead of, say, racking up stacks against frontliners before shifting to the squishy for immediate massive damage.

I was thinking more like the % version of the Armor Pen > Lethality changes.

Assassins and Fighters like Flat Armor Penetration because it's really strong against low armor targets like Marksmen. Riot decided to reduce it's early game snowball potential by altering the stat to reduce armor based on the target's level. So it's still Flat Armor Penetration, but now it won't be as effective on the poor Support that is 3 levels behind and is weaker overall early game in exchange for higher values late game.

I think this can work on Critical Strike too.

Something like a % Bonus Armor shred on Critical Hits. I would still keep the pseudo-RNG element since the unreliability is important in keeping it a late game stat. Obviously, the effect can be powerful if it isn't on every hit early-mid game and having that powerful effect on basically every hit late game is fine if it's balanced around it. This should do 3 things:

1. By making Critical Strike affect only Bonus Armor, it means that Critical Hits in the early game before anyone buys armor do barely any extra damage. This eliminates the "unfair" feeling you get when a huge burst of damage hits you in lane and makes those 1% Crit Chance runes worthless early game.
-
2. By making Critical Strike do % shred, it makes Critical Strike a powerful tank busting stat since it negates damage reduction from armor stacking rather than doing a huge burst of flat physical damage that vaporizes squishy champs.
-
3. By keeping the pseudo-RNG element, it keeps Critical Strike as a late game stat since the damage boost is powerful but reliable until you stack multiple sources of Crit Chance. This helps keep armor a strong option until later in the game and lets Fighters and Tanks have stronger defense in the mid game while still letting Marksmen carry late.

*If needed, you could even make Critical Hits into a stacking shred which each Crit reduces Bonus Armor by X% for Y Seconds* (only for the one scoring Crits, not the whole team). This could be a good way to balance with the Last Whisper items which don't need to be stacked but can be rebalanced to not reduce Bonus Armor as much depending on if it stacks with Critical Strike or becomes mutually exclusive.
